ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Martin, While I don t see as much regularity in our creatures as in Picbreeder or EndlessForms, there still are a lot of symmetries. I just watched the

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=8-1nu4NKDH6n5wlFcai4UflJ-HrqrDhTD-KSQkBB8g29eKl5thSB

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Martin,

While I don't see as much regularity in our creatures as in =
Picbreeder or EndlessForms, there still are a lot of symmetries. I just wat=
ched the video again, and you can see many organisms that have left-right s=
ymmetries (although it is not always easy to see since we're looking at the=
 creatures from the side). Thus I do think that symmetry can, and often doe=
s, help in this system. 

As for whether a sphere is a better starting poin=
t, I don't know the answer to that. It would be fun if someone tested it th=
ough. We've posted all the code for the experiments and the soft-body simul=
ator (available here: http://jeffclune.com/codePublished/softbots2013Code.t=
gz) in case anyone wants to give it a try. If you do, please let us know wh=
at you find. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Scie=
nce
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Apr 16, 2013=
, at 1:56 AM, "martin_pyka" <martin.pyka@...> wrote:

> ok, and would=
 you say, that a sphere provides a better starting point for evolving bilat=
eral symmetric organisms than other starting points? I suppose that this sh=
ould be the case. However, it could be that the objective search favors occ=
asionally deceptive stepping stones (with regard to symmetrical objects).
>=
 
> On the other hand, we have to admit that this is just a property that w=
ould be nice to see in the evolutionary search. We don't know, whether orga=
nisms with a high degree of symmetry would really outperform the organisms =
that you found.
> 
> Best,
> Martin
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff =
Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Martin,
> > 
> > The CPPNs we used hav=
e a distance from center output. So they are easily able to make spheres in=
 the center of the bounding box (by just using that input and ignoring x, y=
, and z). We often saw spherical "rollers" that dropped and expanded part o=
f their sphere to push them away from the origin. So there is nothing in pr=
inciple that prevented them from elaborating on a symmetrical, spherical st=
arting point. 
> > 
> > 
> > Best regards,
> > Jeff Clune
> > 
> > Assistan=
t Professor
> > Computer Science
> > University of Wyoming
> > jeffclune@..=
.
> > jeffclune.com
> > 
> > On Apr 15, 2013, at 6:21 AM, martin_pyka <mart=
in.pyka@...> wrote:
> > 
> > > > > That certainly makes sense. It raises th=
e question of how bilateral symmetry arose in biological organisms.
> > > 
=
> > > I have no link to literature or any kind of evidence, but with regard=
 to this paper I was wondering what kind of creatures would emerge if you w=
ould start with an organism that has spherical symmetry (as far as you can =
represent spherical symmetry with voxels ;)) encoded through a CPPN. This a=
ncestor organism would be something like a unicellular organism in nature. =
Starting with a CPPN of such an organism would mean that radial and bilater=
al symmetry is in actual fact a departure from spherical symmetry. And I su=
spect that from this starting position bilateral symmetry should be easier =
to reach (and it is maybe biologically more plausible!?).
> > > 
> > > @Jef=
f: can you try that for us? :-)
> > > 
> > > From this perspective, complex=
ification (or diversification) would mean breaking the symmetry rather than=
 approaching it, which seems to me more natural. But as I said, I am not fa=
miliar with the literature in this area.
> > > 
> > > Best,
> > > Martin
> =
> > 
> > >
> >
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_D80FBBED-F24D-4C58-A789-4BA1B8888065

<br><div><div>O=
n Apr 16, 2013, at 1:56 AM, "martin_pyka" <<a href=3D"mailto:martin.pyka=
@...">martin.pyka@...</a>> wrote:</div><br class=3D"Apple-in=
terchange-newline"><blockquote type=3D"cite">













<div style=3D"ba=
ckground-color: #fff;">
<span style=3D"display:none"> </span>



    <=
div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>ok, and would you say, that a sphere provides a bet=
ter starting point for evolving bilateral symmetric organisms than other st=
arting points? I suppose that this should be the case. However, it could be=
 that the objective search favors occasionally deceptive stepping stones (w=
ith regard to symmetrical objects).<br>
<br>
On the other hand, we have to =
admit that this is just a property that would be nice to see in the evoluti=
onary search. We don't know, whether organisms with a high degree of symmet=
ry would really outperform the organisms that you found.<br>
<br>
Best,<br>=

Martin<br>
<br>
--- In <a href=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yaho=
ogroups.com</a>, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> Hi =
Martin,<br>
> <br>
> The CPPNs we used have a distance from center ou=
tput. So they are easily able to make spheres in the center of the bounding=
 box (by just using that input and ignoring x, y, and z). We often saw sphe=
rical "rollers" that dropped and expanded part of their sphere to push them=
 away from the origin. So there is nothing in principle that prevented them=
 from elaborating on a symmetrical, spherical starting point.  <br>
> <b=
r>
> <br>
> Best regards,<br>
> Jeff Clune<br>
> <br>
> Assi=
stant Professor<br>
> Computer Science<br>
> University of Wyoming<br=
>
> jeffclune@...<br>
> <a href=3D"http://jeffclune.com">jeffclune.co=
m</a><br>
> <br>
> On Apr 15, 2013, at 6:21 AM, martin_pyka <marti=
n.pyka@...> wrote:<br>
> <br>
> > > > That certainly make=
s sense. It raises the question of how bilateral symmetry arose in biologic=
al organisms.<br>
> > <br>
> > I have no link to literature or =
any kind of evidence, but with regard to this paper I was wondering what ki=
nd of creatures would emerge if you would start with an organism that has s=
pherical symmetry (as far as you can represent spherical symmetry with voxe=
ls ;)) encoded through a CPPN. This ancestor organism would be something li=
ke a unicellular organism in nature. Starting with a CPPN of such an organi=
sm would mean that radial and bilateral symmetry is in actual fact a depart=
ure from spherical symmetry. And I suspect that from this starting position=
 bilateral symmetry should be easier to reach (and it is maybe biologically=
 more plausible!?).<br>
> > <br>
> > @Jeff: can you try that fo=
r us? :-)<br>
> > <br>
> > From this perspective, complexificat=
ion (or diversification) would mean breaking the symmetry rather than appro=
aching it, which seems to me more natural. But as I said, I am not familiar=
 with the literature in this area.<br>
> > <br>
> > Best,<br>
&=
gt; > Martin<br>
> > <br>
> ><br>
><br>
<br>
</p>

    </=
div>
     

    

</div>
